slides.text: Looking back at a year of writing is powerful. You can see how much you have grown — in skill, in confidence, and in voice. Your portfolio will be a lasting record of this growth. Over the next weeks, continue polishing each selected piece. By the end of the year, you will have a collection of writing you can be truly proud of.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student critically evaluate their own writing, select pieces that demonstrate range and quality, write thoughtful reflections, and polish a piece through revision and editing?

parent_notes: The portfolio process is deeply personal and reflective. Your child may be surprised by how much their writing has improved over the year — celebrate this growth explicitly. Help them find all their writing from the year; pieces may be in various notebooks, folders, or digital locations. The selection process itself teaches critical thinking. If your child has difficulty choosing, ask: Which piece are you most proud of? Which one surprised you? Which one makes you feel something when you read it? The cover page design integrates art skills and encourages your child to see themselves as a real writer.

title: Geometry Review — Area and Perimeter Formulas for All Shapes
description: Students review and consolidate area and perimeter formulas for all shapes studied this year: rectangles, triangles, parallelograms, trapezoids, and circles. They create a comprehensive reference sheet and solve multi-step problems.
instructions:
1. Review perimeter: the distance around a shape. Calculate perimeters for several shapes.
2. Review area formulas systematically: rectangle (l × w), triangle (½ × b × h), parallelogram (b × h), trapezoid (½ × (b₁ + b₂) × h), circle (πr²).
3. Review circumference of a circle: C = 2πr or C = πd.
4. Practice applying each formula with numerical examples.
5. Solve composite shape problems: find the area of irregular shapes by decomposing into known shapes.
6. Solve real-world application problems involving area and perimeter.
7. Students create a comprehensive geometry reference card with all formulas and diagrams.
8. Challenge: Solve multi-step problems that combine area, perimeter, and algebra.
9. Work through three olympiad-style geometry problems.
10. Self-assess mastery of each formula and identify any areas needing more practice.

slides.heading: Geometry Review
slides.subheading: Area and Perimeter for All Shapes

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the formula reference sheet with blank spaces for students to fill in. Have graph paper, rulers, and compasses available. Print practice problems of increasing difficulty.

slides.text: This year we have learned area and perimeter formulas for many shapes. Today we bring them all together. For each shape, you need to know: what the formula is, what each variable represents, and when to use it.
Review each formula: Rectangle: A = l × w, P = 2l + 2w. Triangle: A = ½bh, P = sum of all sides. Parallelogram: A = bh, P = 2a + 2b. Trapezoid: A = ½(b₁ + b₂)h. Circle: A = πr², C = 2πr.

Composite shapes are irregular shapes that can be broken into known shapes. For example, an L-shaped room can be split into two rectangles. Find the area of each rectangle and add them together. Sometimes you need to subtract: a shape with a hole requires you to find the outer area and subtract the inner area.

Challenge problems combine geometry with algebra. For example: 'A rectangle has a perimeter of 36 cm and a length that is twice its width. Find the area.' You need to set up an equation (2w + 2(2w) = 36), solve for w, then calculate the area.

slides.prompt: Complete these tasks: (1) Create a geometry reference card with all formulas, labeled diagrams, and one example for each shape. (2) Solve five composite shape problems by decomposing into known shapes. (3) Solve three olympiad-style challenges: (a) A rectangle's perimeter is 48 cm and its length is 3 times its width — find the area. (b) A circular garden with radius 7 m has a 1-m-wide path around it — find the area of just the path. (c) A trapezoid has parallel sides of 10 cm and 16 cm, and an area of 78 cm² — find the height.

slides.text: You now have a complete toolkit for calculating area and perimeter of any standard shape. These formulas will follow you through middle school, high school, and beyond — they appear in architecture, engineering, science, and everyday problem-solving. Your reference card is a valuable resource; keep it in your math folder.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student recall and correctly apply area and perimeter formulas for all standard shapes, solve composite shape problems, and tackle multi-step problems combining geometry and algebra?

parent_notes: This review lesson consolidates geometry skills developed throughout the year. The reference card the student creates is a valuable study tool and the act of creating it reinforces memory. The olympiad-style problems combine geometry with algebraic thinking and require students to work backward from given information — an excellent preparation for middle school math. If your child struggles with any particular formula, focus practice on that shape with hands-on measuring of real objects. Connecting formulas to real life (painting a wall = area, building a fence = perimeter) makes them memorable and meaningful.

title: Global Trade Networks — How Goods Move Around the World
description: Students investigate modern global trade networks, learning about imports, exports, trade agreements, and how goods travel across oceans and continents. They connect modern trade to the historical trade routes studied throughout the year.
instructions:
1. Review historical trade routes studied this year: Silk Road, Triangular Trade, colonial trade networks.
2. Introduce modern trade concepts: imports, exports, trade surplus, trade deficit.
3. Explore how a cargo ship travels from Shanghai to Los Angeles: route, time, and logistics.
4. Discuss major trade organizations and agreements (WTO, NAFTA/USMCA, EU).
5. Analyze a chart showing the top trading partners of the United States.
6. Investigate which products your country imports most and exports most.
7. Discuss the role of ports, shipping containers, and logistics in modern trade.
8. Students create a trade map showing major shipping routes and trading partners.
9. Debate: Are trade agreements beneficial or harmful? Consider multiple perspectives.
10. Write a paragraph connecting one historical trade route to a modern trade network.

slides.heading: Global Trade Networks
slides.subheading: How Goods Move Around the World

slides.setup_instructions: Print trade data charts and shipping route maps. Prepare trade agreement summaries at an accessible reading level. Have the world map prominently displayed for marking trade routes.

slides.text: Throughout history, trade has connected civilizations. The Silk Road linked China to Rome. European explorers opened Atlantic trade routes. The Industrial Revolution created factory goods for global markets. Today, a vast network of ships, planes, trucks, and trains moves goods worth trillions of dollars around the world every year.

Countries import what they cannot produce efficiently and export what they make well. When a country exports more than it imports, it has a trade surplus. When it imports more than it exports, it has a trade deficit. These concepts help us understand economic relationships between nations.

A single cargo ship can carry 20,000 shipping containers. A container ship from Shanghai to Los Angeles travels about 6,500 miles across the Pacific Ocean, taking roughly two weeks. When those containers arrive, they are loaded onto trains and trucks to reach stores across the country.

Trade agreements set the rules for how countries trade with each other — including tariffs (taxes on imports), regulations, and dispute resolution. These agreements can make trade easier and cheaper, but they can also cause controversy when they affect jobs or industries in particular countries.

slides.prompt: Create a trade map and analysis: (1) On your world map, draw the five busiest shipping routes in different colors. (2) Label major ports (Shanghai, Singapore, Rotterdam, Los Angeles, Dubai). (3) Create a chart showing the top five imports and exports of the United States. (4) Write a paragraph comparing one historical trade route to a modern shipping route — what is similar and what has changed? (5) Prepare a position for a mini-debate: Are trade agreements mostly beneficial or mostly harmful? Support your position with evidence.

slides.text: Modern global trade is the latest chapter in a story that began with ancient caravans on the Silk Road. The scale has changed enormously, but the fundamental idea is the same: people benefit from exchanging what they have for what they need. Understanding trade helps us understand our interconnected world — and our shared history.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain imports, exports, and trade agreements, identify major global shipping routes, and draw meaningful connections between historical and modern trade networks?

parent_notes: This lesson brings together history and geography themes beautifully. The scale of modern trade can be hard to grasp — if possible, visit a port, watch videos of container ships being loaded, or track a cargo ship in real time using a marine traffic website. The debate component encourages your child to consider multiple perspectives on a complex issue. Trade agreements are politically charged topics; focus on helping your child understand different viewpoints rather than arriving at a single 'right' answer. This critical thinking about economics connects to the personal finance lessons in practical life.

title: The Respiratory System — Gas Exchange and Lung Mechanics
description: Students explore the respiratory system, learning how air travels from the nose and mouth through the trachea to the lungs, where gas exchange occurs. They model lung mechanics and connect respiration to the circulatory system.
instructions:
1. Begin with observation: count breaths per minute at rest, then after 30 seconds of exercise. Discuss why breathing rate changes.
2. Trace the path of air: nose/mouth → pharynx → larynx → trachea → bronchi → bronchioles → alveoli.
3. Explain the structure of the lungs and the role of the diaphragm in breathing.
4. Build a lung model using a plastic bottle, balloons, and a rubber sheet.
5. Explain gas exchange in the alveoli: oxygen enters the blood, carbon dioxide exits.
6. Connect respiratory and circulatory systems: blood carries oxygen from lungs to cells.
7. Discuss how respiratory health is affected by smoking, pollution, and exercise.
8. Measure lung capacity using a water displacement method.
9. Label a respiratory system diagram.
10. Compare human respiration to how fish, insects, and frogs breathe.
materials_needed: Bowl of water for lung capacity test

slides.setup_instructions: Cut the bottom off a plastic bottle. Insert two small balloons into the bottle as lungs. Stretch a large balloon or rubber sheet over the bottom opening as the diaphragm. Prepare the water displacement setup with a large bowl, water, and a graduated container.

slides.text: Start by counting your breaths per minute while sitting still. Then do jumping jacks for 30 seconds and count again. Your breathing rate increases because your muscles need more oxygen during exercise. But how does air get from outside your body to your cells? That is what the respiratory system does.

Air enters through your nose or mouth, passes through the pharynx and larynx (voice box), then into the trachea (windpipe). The trachea splits into two bronchi — one for each lung — which branch into smaller and smaller tubes called bronchioles, ending in tiny air sacs called alveoli. You have about 300 million alveoli in your lungs.

Build the lung model: the bottle is the chest cavity, the balloons inside are the lungs, and the rubber sheet at the bottom is the diaphragm. When you pull the diaphragm down, air rushes into the lungs (inhale). When you push it up, air is forced out (exhale). Try it!

Gas exchange happens in the alveoli. The walls of alveoli are just one cell thick, surrounded by tiny blood vessels. Oxygen passes from the air into the blood, and carbon dioxide passes from the blood into the air. This is where the respiratory system meets the circulatory system — the blood then carries oxygen to every cell in your body.

slides.prompt: Complete these activities: (1) Build and demonstrate the lung model, explaining how the diaphragm controls breathing. (2) Label the complete respiratory system diagram from nose to alveoli. (3) Measure your lung capacity using water displacement: take the deepest breath you can and blow into an inverted water-filled container — the water displaced equals your lung volume. (4) Create a diagram showing gas exchange at the alveoli, with arrows showing oxygen and carbon dioxide movement. (5) Write a comparison: How is human respiration different from how fish breathe using gills?

slides.text: Every breath you take is a remarkable process involving airways, muscles, and gas exchange at the microscopic level. Your respiratory and circulatory systems work together constantly — delivering oxygen and removing carbon dioxide to keep every cell in your body alive. Next week, we will explore the circulatory system in detail and see how blood carries these gases throughout your body.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student trace the path of air through the respiratory system, demonstrate how the diaphragm controls breathing using the model, and explain gas exchange in the alveoli?

parent_notes: The lung model is a fantastic hands-on activity that clearly demonstrates breathing mechanics. Use a clear plastic bottle so the balloons are visible. The water displacement lung capacity test is fun and generates real data — compare family members' lung capacities and discuss why they might differ (body size, fitness level, age). The connection between respiration and exercise is immediately observable, making this an excellent science-PE crossover. If your child is interested, discuss how altitude affects breathing (thinner air at high elevations) and how athletes train at altitude to increase their red blood cell count.

title: Introduction to Digital Art — Creating with Technology
description: Students explore digital art creation using available technology. They learn basic digital drawing techniques, compare digital and traditional media, and begin to see technology as another tool in the artist's toolkit.
instructions:
1. Discuss the history of digital art: from early computer graphics to modern digital painting.
2. Introduce available digital art tools (tablet drawing app, computer paint program, or phone app).
3. Explore basic digital tools: brushes, layers, undo, color picker, fill.
4. Practice basic techniques: line weight, shading, color blending.
5. Compare the experience of digital vs. traditional art: What is different? What is similar?
6. Create a simple digital artwork using at least three different tools.
7. Discuss how professional artists use digital tools: animation, graphic design, concept art, illustration.
8. Explore the concept of layers and how they allow non-destructive editing.
9. Students create a digital version of one of their traditional artworks for comparison.
10. Reflect: How does digital art fit into your artistic toolkit?
materials_needed: Tablet, computer, or smartphone with drawing app
Printed examples of professional digital art

items: Tablet, computer, or smartphone with drawing app
slides.setup_instructions: Install a free drawing app (Sketchbook, MediBang Paint, or Krita). Set up the device with the app open. Print examples of professional digital art. Have the student's traditional artwork ready for the recreation exercise.

slides.text: Digital art is created using technology — tablets, computers, and specialized software. It is not a replacement for traditional art but an addition to your toolkit. Many professional artists use both digital and traditional media, choosing based on the project.

Explore the basic tools in your drawing app: the brush tool (for drawing), the eraser, the color picker (to choose colors), the fill tool (to fill areas with color), and the undo button (your new best friend — it lets you take back mistakes instantly).

Layers are the superpower of digital art. Think of them as transparent sheets stacked on top of each other. You can draw the background on one layer, the subject on another, and details on a third. If you make a mistake on one layer, the others are unaffected.

Practice these techniques: (1) Create lines of different thicknesses by varying your pressure. (2) Use the opacity setting to create transparent washes of color. (3) Try blending two colors together. (4) Use at least three layers in a single image.

slides.prompt: Create two digital artworks: (1) A free-form digital piece using at least three different tools and two layers. Experiment with brushes, colors, and effects. (2) A digital recreation of one of your traditional artworks — try to capture the same feeling using digital tools. When finished, compare the traditional and digital versions side by side. Write a short reflection: What was easier digitally? What was harder? Which version do you prefer and why?

slides.text: Digital art opens new creative possibilities: infinite undo, easy color changes, layers, and the ability to share your work instantly. But traditional art offers tactile satisfaction, unpredictable happy accidents, and a physical object you can hold. The best artists use every tool available to express their vision. As you work on your capstone art project, consider whether any digital techniques could enhance your work.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student use basic digital art tools (brushes, layers, colors), create a digital artwork, and thoughtfully compare the digital and traditional art-making experiences?

parent_notes: Many excellent drawing apps are available for free: Sketchbook by Autodesk, MediBang Paint, Krita (for desktop), and even basic built-in drawing tools on tablets. A stylus greatly improves the drawing experience on a tablet but is not required. This lesson is not about replacing traditional art but expanding the toolkit. Some children take to digital art immediately while others prefer traditional media — both responses are valid. The comparison exercise (recreating a traditional piece digitally) is particularly educational because it forces conscious thinking about artistic choices. Set appropriate screen time boundaries while still allowing creative exploration.
